1.1 Accidental Release Prevention and Emergency Response Policies



The Dandy Cooling Oxnard Site #2 (DCOX2) Accidental Release Prevention and Emergency Response Policies are simply to not have accidental releases or emergencies. The Company endeavors to execute this policy through the daily implementation of its Safety Programs. Company safety programs include but are not limited to a comprehensive Process Safety Management Program (PSM), which is an integrated approach to the safe operation of processes using Regulated Substances. The PSM Program is specifically designed and intended to prevent accidental releases, and to deal safely with emergencies if and when they do happen. It is the goal of the company to protect its employees, visitors and neighbors from harm due to Company operations. DCOX2 is supported by Western Precooling Systems (WPS), a stakeholder in the refrigeration process.  WPS is a state-wide and reputable supplier of portable ammonia refrigerating equipment and services. 



A "Non-Responding Facility" policy has been adopted; however, the Company recognizes the need to be prepared to safely deal with emergencies. A Hazardous Material Business Plan consistent with Emergency A

ction Plan requirements has been developed and includes emergency procedures, requirements, and information necessary to notify public response agencies and technical resources; the Staff communicate to the Fire Department and evacuate (or shelter-in-place) if there is a release situation or fire. Managers and employees would also shepherd visitors (truck drivers receiving product or delivering product). By effectively determining all persons are safe, the Fire Department can more swiftly manage the tactical part of a response. It is the policy of the company that no-one shall respond to an emergency in a way that is beyond his or her level of training and responsibility.



The facility is supported by Western Precooling Systems (WPS) for ammonia refrigeration maintenance needs. The WPS Oxnard-area regional office and shop are in Oxnard about 6 miles from the site. WPS supports HAZWOPER 1910.120 (q) and Refrigerating Engineers and Technicians (RETA) training for key Refrigerating Technicians and management personnel. These personnel and staff are on-call 24/7/365 to support the Ventura County Fire Department and Mutual Aid Agencies, and the facility, in the event of an emergency. Written procedures that include ammonia specific emergency pre-planning have been developed within the WPS "Thirty Minute Plan". Ammonia-specific emergency equipment is maintained at the WPS Service Shop and in WPS Refrigerating Technician's service vehicles. The company strives to execute its accidental release prevention & emergency response policies through appropriately skilled employees that are provided with adequate equipment and training.



A relationship with Ventura County CUPA is being established. Emergency response pre-planning will be coordinated via regular site visits/inspections and submittal of appropriate EPCRA and other compliance reports. Compliance reports and submittals are updated in accordance with applicable requirements at predetermined intervals. The DCOX2 faci

lity should be included in the County's via filing of the HMBP, including CA Tier II Report.  Key management personnel have received training in the Incident Command System (ICS) training.



1.2 General Description of the Stationary Source and Regulated Substances



Dandy Cooling Oxnard Site #2 is an existing Cooler facility located South of Ventura and West of Oxnard at 5701 West Gonzales Avenue, in a coastal rural setting surrounded by farmland.  The facility is owned by Dole and was previously operated by Dole Berry Company.  Dole ceased operations & decommissioned the refrigerating system in 2014.  Dandy Cooling Company is leasing a portion of the overall site and cooling facilities on a short-term basis.  The overall site occupies 176.6 Acres; with a total building area of 52,084 square feet (two buildings), including one building "A" with 18,150 square feet devoted to cold storage.   The facility "Building A" and surrounding areas was designed for fresh produce pressure cooling, cold storage and shipping, and is the portion being leased by Dandy Cooling Company. The facility is being re-commissioned to provide refrigeration effect for the removal of field heat from freshly harvested vegetables (primarily celery), and subsequent short-term refrigerated storage until it is shipped. Dandy is improving the location with a new Tram and Hydro-Vac vacuum tube pre-cooling unit.  The improvement is being constructed under permit by the County of Ventura Resource Management Agency, according to the codes and standards currently in effect.  The existing refrigeration was designed and installed according to the Codes & Standards in effect circa 2000.      



The product that comes to the facility for vacuum pre-cooling and short-term storage is on site generally for four days from harvesting. The facility is a seasonally operated plant with product harvest periods picking up in the month of November and finishing in July. The remaining months see little fresh product;

1.5 The Emergency Response Program



This plant was specifically designed and engineered to provide for life safety and effective emergency response. Building space is fire-alarm, ammonia alarm and fire-sprinkler equipped. The refrigeration process' Control, Monitoring and Alarm System includes a backup power supply (UPS) and manual backup systems (kill switches). The system initiates notifications, alarms, equipment shutdown and pump-down of the affected area according to the location, nature and severity of the problem. Authorized personnel can access critical process system controls remotely. A KNOX system is coordinated and kept up to date via communications with the Ventura County Fire. The automatic systems and devices are regularly inspected, tested and maintained. Employees are trained in manual discovery, emergency shutdown, evacuation and notification procedures in the highly unlikely event of a failure of the engineered safety and emergency systems.



The Plant does not require its employees to participate in conducting emergency response activities under the HAZWOPER standard; a "Non-responding Facility Policy" has been adopted for the Plant as a whole. In the event of an ammonia emergency, the response is to follow the procedures in the Equipment SOP's and the California Hazardous Material Business Plan (HMBP). The overall procedure is to shutdown critical systems if it can be done safely (via automated system or by qualified personnel), evacuate, and notify the local response agencies and WPS; WPS employs technicians that are 1910.120(q) Hazardous Material Technician certified. Plant employees are to implement hazard communications, provide for the safety of visitors and report to the established Evacuation Staging Area(s) for a head count. Emergency response is coordinated with the County of Ventura Fire & CUPA.  The facility will be included in the County's Emergency Plan via subm

however, the refrigeration equipment is still operative. Major maintenance is performed in the off-season. Operational maintenance is performed on a year-round basis. Company policy requires appropriately pre-qualified personnel to perform technical inspections & maintenance tasks, which are to be done by Western Precooling Systems (WPS).



The Regulated Substance in use is Anhydrous Ammonia, CAS #7664-41-7, which is used in a single closed-loop mechanical refrigeration system which will include the existing system plus the added Hydro-Vac and associated piping Tram. Stationary refrigerating equipment consists of existing Compressors (3), Condensers (2), High Pressure Receiver (1), Accumulators (5), Room Pressure Cooling Units and Evaporators, one portable full-car Hydro-Vac Vacuum Tube and associated controls, instrumentation, piping and an Ammonia-water Diffusion System. The pressure and temperature controls are installed in accordance with appropriate standards, including isolation and overpressure safety relief valves. The Ammonia-water Diffusion System protects safety relief valves from venting directly to atmosphere. An automated control, monitoring and alarm system automatically monitors the system, including ammonia sensors located in the Engine Room and refrigerated building space. The Alarm System is to be supervised 24/7/365 by a third-party alarm company which maintains pre-determined call lists and parameters.  Technicians will be notified directly via .txt if the system approaches out-of-tolerance conditions.  Compressor control panels also include built-in alarms and vibration monitors.



A fire safety suppression system is also installed, including 108,000 gallons water supply, pump house, hydrants, sprinkler connections and controls.  Building space is sprinklered.

   

1.3 General Accidental Release Prevention Program and Chemical Specific Prevention Steps



Accidental Release Prevention Program



A Process Safety Management Plan (PSM) has bee

n established in accordance with CCR 8, 5189.  The PSM Program is specifically intended to promote the safe operation of ammonia-handling equipment and process, and to prevent accidental releases via its elements of Process Safety Information, Process Hazard Analysis, Written Operating Procedures, Training, Mechanical Integrity, Management of Change, Pre-startup Safety Reviews, Hot Work Permits, Compliance Audits, Incident Investigation, and Contractor's Safety.  Other safety programs are integrated with the PSM Program, to the extent practicable, appropriate and/or required (such as the California Injury and Illness Prevention Program/IIPP).  Dandy orchestrates its PSM Program with participation from WPS, Contractors, Consultants and Ventura CUPA.  



Dandy personnel perform daily observations of refrigerating equipment; WPS performs technical inspections, troubleshooting and mechanical maintenance of the equipment.  Schedules and written procedures for the operation and maintenance of ammonia-handling equipment, including the steps to be taken in the event of a release or threatened release, have been developed.  Written procedures include necessary safety precautions for Plant operation, inspection, maintenance, and moving of portable equipment (Hydro-Vac™ Vacuum Tubes).  As inspection and maintenance needs are determined, the need is expressed at the workload meetings conducted by the WPS Area Manager.  The specific task for the expressed need is decided by the WPS Area Manager and entered into the service call system. Tasks are then tracked to completion through the service call system.  Through this regular routine of inspect, discuss, assign and confirmation of completion, Dandy and WPS reduce equipment operational problems and potential for releases.  WPS actively encourages its ammonia technicians to seek Certification through the Refrigerating Engineers and Technicians Association (RETA).  Technicians only perform tasks for which they have been pre-

qualified.



Chemical-Specific Prevention Steps



It had become apparent in the industry that a mishap while draining oil from a system was one of the most common ammonia release incidents to occur.  Special self-closing valves were installed as a solution to this issue.  If a release were to develop during the oil-draining task, the mechanic simply releases the handle of the self-closing valve and flow is terminated.  These types of valves are utilized when oil must be drained from the refrigerating system.



Other Release Prevention Steps:



-  Pressure relief valves are piped to a common header that terminates at an Ammonia-Water Diffusion Tank. 

-  The refrigeration process is equipped with automatic safety cutouts via compressor microprocessor controls.  The cutouts are programmed to shut-down equipment prior to out-of-tolerance conditions being met.  -  Safety cutouts are included in the Maintenance Program and shall be regularly tested for proper actuation. Pressure Relief Valves and the diffusion system are addressed above.

-  A computer monitoring system with battery back-up (UPS) monitors process parameters 24/7/365.  This system is continuously monitored via a third-party security company.

-  The facility is equipped with a Closed-Circuit TV (CCTV) System.

-  The facility is equipped with an automated & permitted fire suppression and alarm system as addressed above.  

-  Fencing and gates limit access by potential "wrong-do-ers".

-  Per PSM a sign-in/sign-out program and security badge system is vigorously enforced.

-  Employees are trained for hazard communication (discovery and communicating) for un-authorized personnel, suspicious activity, fires, releases or other hazardous/suspicious condition.

-  Staff is trained in the fire and accident prevention benefits of good housekeeping.  The general appearance of the facility is maintained on a day-to-day basis.

-  Dandy is committed to work closely with the CUPA.
